questions.clue: This large Canadian lake shares its name with a popular winter sport often played on its frozen surface.
While not located in Russia, this famous Canadian waterfall was named after a city in Russia.
The waters of this Quebec river might not be used for baptisms, but it shares names with a traditional role in one.
Located in Alberta, this turquoise lake is known for its stunning color and is often captured in audio guide tours of the Canadian Rockies.
This largest reservoir in Canada, named after a musical instrument, helps power Alberta’s energy grid and features frozen conditions for much of the winter.
This waterway, shared between Canada and the U.S., is highlighted in the Canadian national anthem and holds significant musical inspiration.
This Russian composer created the 1812 Overture, featuring cannon fire that can be challenging to replicate accurately in audio recordings.
This Italian term describes a vocal piece with a smooth melody and is a popular format for classical music recordings.
Composed by Russian Igor Stravinsky, this ballet score caused a riot at its premiere but later became a staple of 20th-century music.
This versatile French water instrument can mimic the sound of rushing water and has been used in symphonies for Impressionistic effects.

categories.name: Cookie Cutter History: The Science of Baking

questions.clue: When water is added to flour, gluten forms, giving this baked good its chewy texture.
In baking, this ingredient acts as a leavening agent, causing dough to rise through the production of carbon dioxide gas.
A history of Russian tea biscuits showcases how baking traditions traveled with immigrants to this Canadian province known for its sweet butter tarts.
Baking relies on understanding the states of water; this process of turning from liquid to gas helps lighten cakes and muffins.
Named for a territory of Canada, this frosted layer cake has two types of chocolate and was made famous by a recipe contest in Toronto in 1903.
For $200: In rugby, this is the term for the ability to move quickly with the ball after receiving a pass.
For $400: Often known for their scrums, this country is famous for its All Blacks team known for the haka.
For $600: Like a scrum, but lineouts are an alternative for restarting play, typically taking this form.
For $800: This Canadian city hosted the annual Canada Sevens rugby tournament, part of a global series.
For $1000: Known for the standard duration, each half of a rugby union match typically lasts for this many minutes.

categories.name: Frozen, Liquid, and Gas: The States of Water

questions.clue: In rugby, the term 'scrum' can be heard in the field, but on a rink, this happens when the liquid state turns solid.
Canada's Great Lakes contain most of the world's fresh liquid water; name the largest.
This Russian lake, the deepest in the world, represents water in its liquid state and holds about 20% of the world's unfrozen surface fresh water.
In music, this state change occurs when the ice on the 'Glass Tiger's water' turns into a gas during a certain temperature rise.
For the perfect soufflé, oven heat causes water in the batter to change into this gaseous state, creating air pockets.

final.clue: At 540 miles long and holding more fresh water than any other lake in Canada, it shares its name with a province.
